text: Chinstrap penguins have a distinctive black line under their chin.
Macaroni penguins have yellow crest feathers.
Rockhopper penguins jump from rock to rock.
Little blue penguins are the smallest penguin species.
African penguins bray like donkeys.
Galapagos penguins are the only penguins north of the equator.
Yellow-eyed penguins are one of the rarest.
Fiordland penguins have distinctive white streaks.
Snares penguins breed only on Snares Islands.
Erect-crested penguins have upward-pointing crests.
Royal penguins have white faces.
Humboldt penguins live in South America.
Magellanic penguins migrate 3,000 miles.
Penguins can drink salt water.
Penguins have a gland that filters salt from blood.
Penguin feathers trap air for insulation.
Penguins can hold their breath for 20 minutes.
Penguins have solid bones unlike flying birds.
Penguin eggs are incubated on the feet.
Emperor penguin chicks huddle for warmth.
Penguin parents recognize chicks by voice.
Penguins can swim up to 22 mph.
Penguins have excellent underwater vision.
Penguins are countershaded for camouflage.
Penguins have spines on their tongues.
Some penguins mate for life.
Penguin colonies can have millions of birds.
Penguins preen to maintain waterproofing.
Penguins have excellent hearing underwater.
Penguin ancestors could fly.
The oldest penguin fossils are 62 million years old.
Ancient penguins were 6 feet tall.
Penguins evolved in the Southern Hemisphere.
Penguins are related to albatrosses.
Penguin wings evolved into flippers.
Penguins lost flight 65 million years ago.
Seals and sea lions are penguin predators.
Leopard seals are major penguin predators.
Orcas hunt penguins in some regions.

Giant petrels attack penguin chicks.
Penguins face threats from climate change.
Overfishing reduces penguin food supplies.
Oil spills devastate penguin populations.
Plastic pollution affects penguins.
Some penguin species are endangered.
Penguin guano is valuable fertilizer.
Penguin colonies affect local ecosystems.
Penguins spread nutrients from sea to land.
Penguin behavior is studied to understand climate change.
Satellite tracking reveals penguin migration patterns.
Flipper bands help identify individual penguins.
Penguin cameras show underwater hunting.
Drones count penguin populations.
Genetic studies reveal penguin evolution.
Penguin poop is visible from space.
Penguin colonies are studied from satellites.
Robot penguins infiltrate colonies for research.
Penguin vocalizations are analyzed by computers.
Thermal cameras detect penguin body heat.
Penguin feathers inspire waterproof materials.
Penguin swimming inspires submarine design.
Penguin huddles inspire heating systems.
Penguin feet stay warm through heat exchange.
Penguin blood vessels minimize heat loss.
Penguins can reduce blood flow to extremities.
Penguin fat provides insulation and energy.
Penguins can fast for months while breeding.
Male emperor penguins fast for 115 days.
Penguins produce crop milk to feed chicks.
Penguin immune systems fight cold-water pathogens.
Penguins have more feathers per square inch than other birds.
Penguin eyes adjust quickly between air and water.
Penguins see well in low light.
Penguin hearing is tuned to colony sounds.
Penguins navigate using the sun and stars.
Penguins may sense Earth's magnetic field.

Penguins pant to cool down.
Penguins flush blood to flippers to release heat.
Penguin metabolism slows during fasting.
Penguins can recycle body heat.
Penguin kidneys efficiently conserve water.
Penguins have excellent depth perception.
Penguin brains are adapted for underwater hunting.
Penguins can detect bioluminescence.
Penguin stomachs can digest whole fish.
Penguins regurgitate food for chicks.
Penguin chicks have different down than adults.
Young penguins form creches for protection.
Penguin chicks can recognize parents by voice.
Penguin pairs share parenting duties.
Some penguins breed in burrows.
Penguins defend territories within colonies.
Penguin courtship involves displays and calls.
Penguins bow to their partners.
Penguin pairs strengthen bonds through preening.
Penguin eggs need constant warmth to develop.
Failed penguin eggs are sometimes 'adopted' by others.
